Fort Concho, Texas
May 14 1879
My Dear General:
I guess I will write a Political letter this time, though I am not a politician, and furthermore not supposed to have any politics,
I think while you are East, it would be a good idea to see some of your friends in Congress on the subject of the present promotion, and I begin to think, that as we now have a Democratic Congress and Senate with about an Even chance for the next President to be Democratic, and in view of the fact also, that several attempts have been made to throw open the doors of the Army & Navy, to Ex Confederates, that they will declare all the present vacancies

in Regiments to the Original, and try to have them filled by Ex Rebel soldiers. This is of course impossible with the present President, but will it be improbable should the Government pass Entirely into the hands of the Democrats, and in view of the above facts, do you not think it would be proper and just for the President to have the Old Officers (General and Field) who are disabled by wounds, Disease, and who are over sixty-two, or who have served forty years, Retired and their places now filled with others who would be likely to remain for the next 8 or 10 years. The Senate would have to confirm them unless an act was passed reducing the Army - which would of course have to run the chances of a vets? during Hayes' administration.
No Ex Confederates are young Enough to come in as 2? Lieutenants. and

I believe that beforr two years rolls by an attempt be made to put them into the Army or to reinstate them to their old positions which they held beforr the war. and then assign them to vacancies which now Exist and are not being filled. All this imagination on my part may be a little premature, but I am certain of one thing, and that is, the Democratic Party are very uncertain, and very unreliable.
I write the above for you to think of, and hope I may be wide from the mark in my opinions as to the future,
Do You not think I had better resign and go into Politics.
Should you go to Washington, and have an opportunity to see my old Colonel do so, and give him my best wishes. By the by, I see that Captain

Rockwell has got a bill through Congress correcting his record and allowing his services to be counted while acting during the War as a volunteer aid-de-camp. Now would be a good time for you.
Mrs Smither, wishes to be remembered. and all the officers send regards Etc.
Sincerely Yours,
R. G. Smither
1 Lieut & Adjt 10 Cavly.
P.S. Lieut Harmon has been ordered before a Board again, and Gasmann recommended by Genl Ord.
Smither.

To Genl. B. H. Grierson           Fort Concho
U. S. Army, Texas.                   August 6" 1880.
My Dear General.

                I want to congratulate you on your success, and hope that it may prove successful throughout and that you may yet carry off the honors of making an end to Victoria and his Nomads,  We could not get any news of your fight here for three or four days, the first we received after your telegram to Mrs. Grierson, was a copy of your telegram (by mail.)  from Stockton, and I feel a little ashamed of not being with you, and I want to say that I am ready to come whenever you say so.  I keep your records posted up as fast as I receive them, and now have my workups

to July first in the Regiment, have made out and forwarded the descriptive list of recruits.  Have received the invoices of the new desks and blank case, also invoices of one set of Brigade books for Regimental Headquarters (old patten)   I have had a couple of spats with the chief quartermaster on the book business, but they finally come down a little  I tell you, you have to fight for it, or they wont give you anything.  I am not done with them yet on the printing press business, and I am going to get Colonel Mills to try and influence the Quartermaster General on the subject of a printing press, and he may be able to assist me a little  All this is for the benefit of the next Adjutant, and the Regiment.

Major Mills has been laid up with rheumatism, Major Schofield ordered to duty at Concho, but since put on duty as a member of Horse Board at San Antonio.

       Nordstrom got off a few days since for up the country, but from remarks I have heard made, I presume he did not want to go
       Chaplain Weaver, here, I do not know how much account he is as preacher, but he seems active and willing, and full of talk, He has been placed on duty as Post Treasurer.
       H. Clay Burke, has not succeeded in getting an expression from the Four Green County Democracy, as he desired.
       I have just teid up one of Colonel Mills' Belts and will send it to you by tomorrows

Headquarters District of the Pecos,

                Fort Concho, Texas, Aug. 22nd, 1880

Dear General,

      A Number 34, has sprung in your rear the same as did for Hatch.  I send you two slips cut from the San Antonio Express of the 15" & 18" instant.-   I also enclose you a letter that I sent Genl. Vincent today, with a view of showing who these "Reputable Citizens" are, and hope my action will not displease you.
        There is a man-station Keeper at one of the stations between Quitman and El Muerto, who has written a letter here to either Mr Veck, or some Saloon keeper, saying that you were whipped in the first engagement, that the men were brave enough but the officers were Cowardly, that the

Indians held the ground and feasted off of the animals killed, that the man of "C" Co. was only wounded and was abandoned and fell into the hands of the enemy.  This mans name is Riley.  I give you his name as I first reported that he was one of your citizen teamsters.  Veck Burke & Co. are having a jollyfication over this letter, from all accounts.

       I know it is best for to pay no attention to such characters, but when they attempt to attack you behind your back I cannot help but let my dutch get up to boiling heat.
       The Regiment has been reduced from 850 to 800 enlisted men.  I issued an order today fixing the number of men to each company   Keyes has an excess of three men, had I not

better transfer three  men from his company - 800 hundred men gives as follows.

    N. C. S.  five men, three Companies 67 and the remainder 66 men each, I made the senior Company A. and D. and M.  the 67 men companies, the two latter having 67 and 70 men each.
    Captain Thomas J. Spencer, wife and child were in the town of San Angella, a few days since I did not know of it, in fact it was not known until today.  I presume he had business in another direction, and thought best not to call at Regimental Hd. Qrs., make him join Company: do him good, and he might if he would stand long enough-save the live of some man by stopping a bullet.  I have never heard anything about the letter relative to his conduct at Chicago or since

it was forwarded.

          Ame's case closed some days ago.-
          The grass here is excellent and have had a great deal of rain.
          I lost a man during the last freshet of the North Concho River, Samuel F. Williams.  I am sorry about it, as he was beginning to be a valuable man in the band, his body was recovered two [strike] 3 days after.
        We have the finest baby you ever seen, have name it Mabel Roberta.  I fear Mrs Smither will not be able to give it nourishment, the servant business give me a great deal of worry.  We all want to hear from you, and I would like to have been with you.  Kindest regards to Robert, Sincerely Yours
                                       etc.  Robt. J. Smither
                                               Adjutant 10th Cavalry

To 
Genl B. H. Grierson
[written upside down at top of page]
P. S.   Major Mills has been sick for a long time but now improving he will probably leave next Tuesday for the East.

Fort Concho, Texas, August 22d  1880.
General Thomas M. Vincent,

               U. S. Army
               San Antonio, Texas.

Dear General:

    The "San Antonio Express" of the 15th instant contains an article purporting to be the statement of Judge Allen Blacker, reflecting upon the management of troops by General Grierson, while operating against Victoria and his band of marauders.
    The statements of Judge Blacker, if correctly reported, are so much at variance with General Grierson official report, that I desire to say:  from knowledge of the habits of Judge Blacker, they must either emanate from his seggy and alcoholic brain, or they are the wild imaginations of a scared man, while en route from El Paso.
    From my knowledge of the Country I know that General Grierson has reported nothing but

facts, and he is more inclined to under, than over estimate, and there is no officer in the Army who has more endurance and determination of character than General Grierson, that he has succeeded in keeping Victorio and his band of outlaws from the settlements, is a fact too well know, to need any comments from me, or any one else, and Mr. Blacker could not obtain any information along the line of stage travel - except from stage men, and station keepers, that would warrant his making any such statements, as the country between Forts Quitman and Davis, is entirely unsettled.

    In the same paper of the 18th instant appears an Editorial, which seems to be based upon information alleged to have been received from private parties,  In this connection, I also desire to state, that the "reputable Citizens" referred to, by this impartantial Editor, is one Wm. S. Veck, ho resides at the Town of San Angello alias Fort Concho, Texas, and who is the author or instigator of these "private advices, in fact I have

heard repeatedly of his making threats to do such a thing, and have information to the effect, that he has himself - or got others to do so, written to the Editor of the San Antonio Express, that at such a time such and such persons would arrive at San Antonio, leave him or them interviewed on the management of Indians, etc.  This man Veck has had, or did have a poor Vagabond, by the name of Henry Clay Burke, to do his dirty work in the way of letter writting, he Veck being incapable to do it, these two "reputable Citizens, who are situated at very safe distance, some 360 miles, from the scene of Indian troubles, take this means of venting their for General Grierson, and thus it will be seen that such characters are only plying their daily vocation of lying which, then can do without the least compunction.

    Papers emanating from these two men, have been received at this post, which show their true characters, and in the absence of General Grierson, I have taken the liberty of thus writing

you, with a view of ascertaining, if such publications cannot be prevented by the Editor of the San Antonio Express, and at a time when General Grierson is absent in the field and cut off from all communication.

   General Grierson has done more hard work to develop the resources and keep the Indians out of this part of Texas during the past three years, than has ever been done heretofore.
               Very respectfully
                     Your obedient Servant
             (signed)   Robt. G. Swither
                             1st Lieut. and Adjt. 10th Cavalry
                                A. A. A. General

Fort Concho, Texas,
August 29" 1880.
My Dear General,

               Have just entered last batch of letters and telegrams that were received from you, in the district books.
   The new desks have been received, have been having them ironed by Jordan, they were made out of pine, but are quite an improvement on the old desk, being roomy and well  made, also received blank case,
    The Regimental book business was, after some growling on the part of the Adjutant, and with General Vincent's assistance, a success. received a set of books, with the exception of letter received book, the same as those now in use, and if I can interest Davis, I think

I can obtain a letter received book by getting him to ask for a Quartermasters book, which is just what I want.

            I now want to try and get some new horses, by getting authority for Schofield to select them, to mount the Non-Commissioned staff officers of the regiment, so you see I am compelled to have something to do, to keep me out of mischief, and I want to "hood-wink" the Post treasurer into buying my printing press, and then for me to get a self inker.
    Upon the receipt of the Copy of your telegram to Department Headquarters, relative to Burke telegram, about the checks, etc. I made copy of it and enclosed it in communication, and endorsed all the facts of the case, and stated that Mr. Burke well knew his telegram was false when he forwarded it, and gave good reasons why he

knew it was false.

    General, I have sent you several papers lately, which have contained many articles purporting to be from different parts of the Country, relative to yourself and troops, the "Concho Times" published a letter of Colonel Johnsons, and it will make some of the gentleman over the creek a little mad, as it was intended for their benefits,  I am going to answer that one in the paper from my home, and will send you a copy when it is published Dr. Smith says he will help me.  It would serve these devils in Texas, right, if they were left alone to themselves.  In my opinion the most of these letters have their origin at San Angelo, that Burke and Veck are at the bottom of the whole business.  Mrs. Grierson just showed me a piece in the [strike] a Dallas [strike] Fort Worth of August 25th paper which contains some statements of the chiddesters, the stage people,

Camp near Presidio, Tex.
May 1st  1882.
General B. H. Grierson
Fort Davis, Texas.
Dear General,

              Will I be permitted to address you semi officially or not, or are you still mad at those tabulated statement on the subject of hay & corn.  Somebody must have gone wrong or lost their balance or perhaps a little deficient on the subject of arithmetic.  Never mind General, the "Padre" is going to assemble his flock of Mexicans, goats and Jack-_____ in a few days and ascend the mountains near here and pray for rain, that will fix the whole matter, provided it is not kept up.  The above is the "Semi" part, the following official or whatever you may call it.
              I want a spring wagon, my

buggy is something like the post Quartermasters hay, the thing has "shrunk up" and I am afraid it will fall to pieces.  I and Jones do not want a spring wagon, but our families are shut up here with the children like two old hens with two children each - and besides if I should get a sick man I would have no way to send him in.  I do not want any more of your mules, but just the wagon.   Now if you do not think we need a spring wagon you climb into that old cart of yours and come and see us.  I think if I could get you away from the bad influence that surround you at Davis you would send us a wagon.   My sergeant can bring it down by making a spike team or two.

If you will send the spring wagon you need not answer this letter.

                       I start to grazing tomorrow and will make the hay last until some time in June, perhaps the greater part of mo. there is no grass here until it rains.
       This is a very find country, and its pleasant surroundings from a sandy point of view, are not to be excelled by any watering places along the sea shore, come one, come all; but do not forget the spring wagon or at least a cart or wheel-barrow, anything suitable to ride in.
                         Yours as ever
                            R. G. Smither

Camp near Presidio, Texas,
May 6th 1883.
Dear General:

         Your sudden arrival and sudden departure made me forget to show you the old Cart and Harness at this post, both of which are sadly in need of new ones, Cant you have me new ones sent, there is nothing good about the cart except the axle, and part of the bed the wheels are absolutely worthless, and they should have been added to the list of unserviceable stores, that is the Cart and Harness.
       What I want to write about is this, the cattle of Mrs. Brennen, you know there were 37 head, over half of them are from sucking calves up to 2 year old,  did you mean to pay her $16.50 per head all around, or to pay that for the large, if the latter

what are the limits for the young. 2 should not a cow and calf go as one, please answer me this right away.  The boy told me that he expected his mother in three days, and he also said she would not take less than $18.00 per head, but could not say whether that meant for the older or large ones or to include the small stock.  Also let me know what is the most you will pay.

    You should have remained here last night and taken a good view of the sand storm in the vicinity and about Presidio:  We had a fearful storm, the Guard tents that you condemned were blown into "smitherenes" the wind blew like forty, and we are shovelling out the dust now.  I think about 1000 acres of sand came over the river

last night.

                  Do not forget the leather and paint, also plenty of oil, as the Canvass takes a fearful amount of paint.
          I wish you would fill me up when the recruits come as I have about 20 men on duty every day here, 6 guards, 6 on extra duty, about 8 or 9 daily duty men.  I can not reduce them very much as I have a Hospital & Commissary to run besides a man in charge of the Property
          The people are wondering what you were here for, and have the post fever again.
           We all send our best wishes to Mrs Grierson,
                          As Ever
                                       Smither
                                       Captain
            

General B. H. Grierson.

San Carlos  May 27  1886.
My dear General,

              We arrived here on the 21st after a hard march over a tough country, my troop is scattered everywhere to try and head off or intercept the Indians reported coming this way.  I have 12 horses left and have rations ready, in saddle pockets to start in any direction,   this is the worst hole in the country no shelter for men and horses and excessively warm.  I have been about 2/3 sick for several days and my leg is troubling me terribly keeping me awake, I have med up my mind to ask to be ordered before a Retiring Board as it is impossible for me to climb these mountains as I should do in case of necessity, and therefore I desire to ask you to send me soon as possible a statement as to my willingness for duty and

anything else that your think would be of benefit to me.  I hate terribly to think of giving up my troop and can hardly bear to think of doing so, but I am unable to do hard work and feel that some more active man should have my place.  I would like to have Woodward get the troop instead of Beck, my nervous system is such that it is impossible for me to get any rest, I shall go on and do my best with all the energy I have.

                 I have written Mrs. Swither to sell out and go home, as she could not endure it.  I shall construct shades, so soon as I can do so, for men and horses.  I told Mrs. Swither to sell the ponies and buggy also,  this place is much warmer than Presidio, Texas, ever got to be.
                I feel like breaking up my own home when I think of leaving the army, but I am satisfied that it is

best for me or become a total wreck.

              Sincerely your &c
                        Robt. G. Smither
                         Capt. 10 Cav.

P. S.

    The reason I want your statement is to prevent them from thinking me a shirk, simply because I was sent here, but you know me and I want you to state frankly what you think, whether to my benefit or not, and if you can use any influence so that Woodward can get the troop, do so, as I would not like to see Beck or Nordstrom get it.
                                                      Smither

San Carlos, A. T.
June 18" 1886.
My dear General:

              Well this is a lovely place and strongly reminds me of Presidio-del-Norte, Texas, so far as heat is concerned and very much worse as to looseness of soil in a wild storm.   My troop has been scattered from Huachucha, to Apaceh, on the North and South and Fort Thomas on the East, besides others in the numerous mountains, however I got them all in last night, but sent four more out this morning dismounted to Wilcox.  I must confess that I am not in love with San Carlos.  Hughes has been somewhere on detached service ever since I arrived here and returned last evening with very sore eyes.  I am sorry they took Jones from me now, when I have to send out so many detachments, as the detachment that was

out with Watson came in with every horse disabled besides having to leave one at Apache.  I have hauled poles and forts for from 10 to 12 miles to build shelter for horses and men.   Can you not get Jones sent back to me?   I have not been well since I have been here as I caught a heavy cold and have been having Bronchitis, but have kept myself busy and not had time to get sick.

   Col. Mills, commands this District and he tried his best to pull my troop all over the country in detachments, but he is now in El Paso some-where.  Col Van Vliet is in command at Thomas.
    Keyes and Ward have been tried, Keyes has gone to join his troop, Ward is still retained in arrest at Grant. Lee is now being tried.  Ward objected to Col. Shafter sitting on his court, he evidently does not swear so much by Col. Shafter as he used to do.
    I do not know the troubles of Lee,

and I guess Mills, as usual, avoids being placed on the witness stand.

    Mrs. Smither, says you think of going to Santa Fe.  Can't you get B troop assigned there and take her with you.   I am afraid she will worry herself sick after you all leave.  I sometimes think my being sent here was due to remarks made by some of those who were so anxious to get away from Thomas, and go to Apache.  Capt. Pierce says he never asked for any troop, and before I arrived Maj. Mills said he did not want me at Thomas, but to put me in Camp here.  This place is destitute of grass, it having been eaten off by the Indian stock and it has not rained for so long that everything is burned up by heat, and the water is the San Carlos very low.
    The Indians here are at work and need good control, the scouts they have employed seem to be obedient and reliable and certainly do anything you tell the, the will arrest their own people without any question about it.

I am in hopes to hear that I may go with you to Santa Fe, should you go there.

    With best wishes to Mrs. Grierson and all friends, and Woodward.
                            Sincerely yours
                                 Robt. G. Smither
                                    Captain 10 Cavalry

I would rather do anything else than leave the service, but something seems to break me up pretty rapidly in this climate, and especially at that place of San Carlos, and of General Miles had not have been so persistent in keeping my troop there simply because I was junior to Pierce I might have wiggled along awhile longer, but I guess it is best I should go and settle down somewhere.  I presume you very probably know that they have ordered two companies of Infantry there and two of Cavalry, I should

liked to have seen old Viele sent there instead of Morrison, and Cooper next, the both of them are boot licks and I have heard they told Miles that they had been in all the mean places where ever the regiment had been stationed or something to that effect.  The Indians have become so restless during the past few months that they have got to be handled a little carefully.  There is one thing I want to say to you, and in doing so I want to do no injustice to Lt. Johnson for he deserves all the credit he has received for the last campaign, but Lieut. Hughes deserves equal credit, if not more.  Hughes was the first to take up the trail, and was one of the last to leave it after they had driven the Indians back towards the reservation in fact on to the reservation and with his detachment from my troops worked hard & faithfully.  I simply

mention this because I want you know that Hughes is deserving of very much credit, and it was due to him that Johnson joined him on the trail.  Hughes is desirous of having another officer assigned to the troops as the work is too much for one officer, and he dislikes papers so much, besides he wished to get a leave this fall.  Reade has been made A. C. S. and Commissary here, but I would like to see Jones join the troop if it was possible, yet I presume they will not let him do so.  I learn that milles and Miles are quite congenial and are purchasing Read-Estate together over in the Los Angeles country.

    We are living from hand to mouth here, having partly packed up, and presuming I would get my leave or surgeon's certificate, but twice it came back the last time for som informality, but stated it would be favorably considered, but of course there is no telling what they

(You can address me at Thomas at present)

To the Editor of the Indianapolis News,

   The truth of the matter is simply this, and you may depend upon it, I do not receive my information second hand.
   About the middle of June, Victorio and his band of marauders having been driven out of the mountains of New Mexico by General Hatch into Old Mexico, it was officially reported that in all probability the wily old chieftain and his murdering clan would attempt to cross back to the territory of the United States somewhere near old Fort Quitman, an abandoned post on the Rio Grande, ninety miles below El Paso and one hundred and thirty five miles west of Fort Davis.  To meet this threatened invasion of Texas, General G....[strike] Grierson, commanding the military "District of the Pecos" immediately proceeded to concentrate all the available troops of his district at such points as would enable him to protect the few scattered settlements and punish the marauders.  To do this effectually the country being one of magnificent distances and almost devoid of water

(3).
it was necessary for him to divide his troops up
in such commands as would enable them to watch
the country and prevent the indians from crossing
the stage road without first becoming engaged with the
troops and being held at bay until reenforcements could
be sent [strike 2 words] reach the threatened point.  While these movements

for concentration General Grierson received notice the
Indians would likely attempt to get through his lines
and were moving in the direction of his camp.  He
was at the time, July 30th encamped with only seven
men, in one of the passes between the Eagle and
Quitman mountains.  Now what did he do?  He
did not do, as would have been done by the so-called
fighting people of this country, referred to by may
reliable (?) brother townsman, get up and run, but
with these seven men, he fortified his position with
such means as were available against Victorio and
his whole band and sent for troops to reenforce him, 
before these troops arrived however he was joined by
Lieutenant Leighton Finley with thirteen men of the 10th
Cavalry, making twenty men in all, and with this small
detachment, he held Victoria's whole band at bay for
two hours, until troops from Eagle Springs, one company
and part of another↑ of the 10th Cavalry, about forty men arrived, when
the General assumed the offensive and a sharp action
took place and was going on, when at the approach
of another company ↑ of the 10" Cavalry from Quitman, the Indians fled

(4)
rapidly to the Rio Grande and crossed back into old Mexico.  The Indians in this engagement suffered severely, having seven killed and many wounded. The troops lost one solider killed and one officer wounded.  The command was then moved in the direction of Van Horns wells where it was thought the Indians would make their next attempt to get through the lines and go North.  While the troops were engaged guarding the passes in the mountains to the East of Van Horns wells and scouting towards the Rio Grande to prevent the Indians from passing towards the settlements.  Victorio and his band slipped through the lines west of Van Hornes on August 4th.  General Grierson at once moved his command in pursuit and after a forced march of sixty five miles in twenty one hours without the loss of an animal, succeeded in heading Victorio off and after a sharp engagement the Indians were again defeated and driven back, for the second time, across the Rio Grande, badly demoralized and with the loss of many killed and wounded, one hundred horses, their camp and all their provisions.

    They are now in Telexico, at least one hundred and fifty miles to the westward of Fort Quitman and have gone via of [strike] the Saute Maria river in the direction of Sierra De Guzman. Scouts report the Indians in a decidedly demoralized condition, having their wounded with the, and their stock played out; as an evidence of which, they were

(5)
nearly all marching on foot driving their animals, avoiding their usual trails, passing over and skirting the roughest broken country.

    From the 28th of July when they first crossed the river into Texas, until the 12th of August when Victorio with the last of his entire force was the second time driven back into Telexico, the loss of the Indians in the fights at Tinaja De Deos Palmes and at Rattlesnake canon and in the several skirmishes were certainly not less than thirty killed and wounded, and very probably over forty, as the remains of several Indians lately killed and fresh Indian graves have been found in the vicinity of the Indian trails and their late camps: and without fresh horses and rest to recuperate, they are not now in a condition to act in a body against any organized force.
    In this short and energetic campaign Victorio and his band were badly whipped and driven across the Rio Grande into Telexican territory where the United States forces cannot follow them.  The troops engaged in this good work belong in this District, and both officers and men deserve the highest commendation for their success in protecting the settlements and driving the Indians out of the country before they could do any damage.

(6)
just returned from the frontier" cannot change the fact one particle.  The troops engaged do not object to criticism when it has some basis but they most decidedly object to gratuitous abuse from one, who I venture to assert was not within three scene of operations and has Pecos river.

    The newspapers, and gentlemen who seem so anxious to censure the troops for not capturing or entirely distroying the Indians, do not stop to consider the difficulties to be encountered in consummating this desirable result.  They appear to be ignorant of the nature and extent of the territory to be scouted over; the absence of water, except at widely, separated points; the difficulty of transportation and communication; the poverty of the country in cereals and other necessary supplies for men and animals; the rough and almost inaccessible mountain ranges to be traversed and a thousand and one other obstacles to success.

    In regard to the statement about the West Pointers engaged let me assure my fellow townsman, there was only two from the Academy; all the other officers serving with General Grierson and his command, with the exception of three, were appointed from civil life and served during the war of the Rebellion and have "smelled the patchies" on many warmly contested battlefields.
    The assertion that the 'colored troops exhibited

(7)
cowardice and kept out of contact of [strike] with Victorio and his warriors is a willful lie and my friend forgot when he made the statement, that he was making it to quite a number of colored ex-soldiers of your city who would not fail to deny the accusation.
The colored troops have exhibited the noblest courage on more than one occasion and the taunt of cowardice illy suits a class of men who generally expose themselves unnecessarily to the fire of the enemy.

    As to the beautiful Mexican ladies my fellow townsman mentions, I think he must have become enamored with the "Yellow Rose of Texas", for I confess during my many years of service on the frontier I have never seen a beautiful Mexican woman.  I have met with a few fair looking ones, but the larger majority of those you meet out here are greasy, sallow complected, jaundiced looking specimens of humanity, half starved and with a chronic expression of liver complaint.  If my friend admired this class of women, I wont quarrel with him over a little matter of taste.
  And now in conclusion let me contradict my friend once more by stating there has not been a settlement in Western Texas molested by Victorio and his marauders, for the simple reason that the Indians were compelled by General Grierson to confine their movements to a limited ares of the most God-forsaken, desolate country in the United States, and when any other description of the

went after them.  Went beyond the North Fork of Red river and returned last night.  Ran into a party, supposed to be the ones who had run off. Camp Wichita I. T.
April 27, 1869
Dear General,

                 Things are moving as usual, but there is a general grumbling on account of the short rations.  They consist of very poor [2 words underline] beef without salt, very coarse Corn mean without salt and coffee without sugar.  No beans, rice or vegetables, no salt meat, and no officers stores of any description.   We daily expected trains with supplies, but as none come, when the flour gave out we sent eight of the post wagons to Arbuckle after rations, but it will be at least a week before they return.   Bad roads and high water are no excuse now for this.  Every wagon in the District east of here should be loaded with rations and supplies for this place.
   Last Sunday, the Arrapahoes and the

Cheyennes who had not ran off the week before were encamped at Chandler's Ranch, having gone that far on their route to Camp Supply.  About 4 o'clock P. M. some teamsters came in and reported that a Cheyenne had shot one of their comrades.  Soon after Little Raven's son came in and corobborated the story.  Major Kidd with 25 men went out to investigate it.  I went with him.

  The story is this.  They Cheyennes had made up their minds to leave.  A woman wanted to go with them and her husband wanted to remain with the Arrapahoes.  They quarreled about it and he whipped her whereupon her son, to vent his anger for the whipping of his mother, determined to go out and kill a whiteman.  As soon as the deed was done the Cheyennes cleared out stock and flute.  We did not think it worth while to run down horses to go after them.  The man is badly shot in the neck with an arrow, but is doing well.  He is here in hospital.  Little Raven sent out and

drove in the mule herd and took the train into his camp to protect it against any farther depredations by the Cheyennes, and yesterday morning they all got well under way in change of Lieut. Lee with four men.  The delay in starting was caused by the heavy rain which raised Medicine Bluff Creek so that it was not fordable.  Cache Creek is now
scarcely fordable.   There was no interpreter to go with Lee and I did not think it proper to let him go off under the circumstances without one.  The boy Jack Fitzpatrick who was to have gone with him, went off with Hazen, so I got Capt. Penney to let Morrison go with the promise to let him use Jones when he wanted him until Morrison returned.  So the Cheyennes may now all be counted on the war-path, but the Arrapahoes are all right and I have no doubt will go to their reservation in good faith.

    Harmon just returned this evening,

having killed another of the horse thieves, "Summers", a deserter from the 7th Cavalry, and captured one "Williams", beside recovering nine horses and ponies.

   I have to send out four men in the morning to relieve the citizen Couriers between here and Arbuckle.  I shall send dismounted men and let them take the mules now on the line.  We are having lovely weather now and your house is progressing well.  It is boarded in all round.
   I look for a letter from you by the morning mail.  Have not had a word since you left.  Capt. Alvord has come on the train and I think intends to leave in a few days without authority.
   Kind regards to Mrs. Grierson and Mrs. Sample.
                        Truly yours,
                           S. L. Woodward

April 28th. Mail just in, but nothing from you.  The mail from Gibson is evidently delayed somewhere.

Camp Wichita I. T.
May 4th 1869
Dear General

          Yours of Apl. 20th arrived yesterday, also a number of communications from Dept. Hd. Qrs. with notes of instruction from you.  The order revoking Col. Rockwell's orders to come here goes down by this mail, also an order to C. O. Ft. Gibson to cover the sending of two companies to Fort Smith.  I received an order from Dept. Hd. Qrs. modifying Col. Huston's orders so that he will stop at Gibson instead of Arbuckle.  Shall I order Hd. Qrs. 6th Infantry to Gibson?
Mails have been detained in consequence of high water in the Washita, sinking the ferry boat.  It is all right again however.
  The parade on the plateau is being fenced.  Captain Gray has his company quarters under way, the front wall nearly up.  Your house is going on a little slow, but

I dont see how we can hurry it ↑ The stone work is all done except the chimney & they are working on that.  The office will soon be done, but I have no window sash for it, and see no way of getting them except from Gibson.  I want six for it, each six eights 8 x 10 glass.  Will you order them up, also some locks for the doors.  It is oppressively warm today.  Rations are still very scarce and we can hear of none on the way.  The eight wagons we sent to Arbuckle after commissary stores returned here yesterday, bringing about half of all that is at Arbuckle and only about 15 days rations for us.  No flour, all hard tack.  We have been living on corn meal for the past two weeks.  Some sickness in consequence.

  If Col. Rockwell can send me some sash, I wish he would send about a dozen, so I can have some for my private quarters when I start to build them
  The company commanders except Capt. Rife are all hauling in logs for their company quarters.  It is very important that the

men be got out of their gopher holes as soon as possible.  During the last heavy rain, they were all filled with water.  My office business is all well up and running very smoothly.  Please send me any official documents, orders, letters &c, which you have not already sent me, that I may have them filed in their proper places and entered in the books.   I hope rations are now enroute from Gibson.  If not, we shall be in a very tight place before this month is out.  Kind regards to Mrs. Grierson and Mrs. Sample.  All well here except Mrs. Boone whom the Doctor thinks will not live till morning.  Capt. Penney moved down to Hazen's farm yesterday.  He has thrown up his hand on the Indian farming for want of funds and Col. Boon has taken charge of it.  

  The Indians who have never been in are all reported as coming in. ↑ A number of the [strike] Quarades are here.

Enclosed is a letter for you which came yesterday.

                                 Yours truly
                                     S. L. Woodward

May 5th 6 A. M.

  Mail in this morning, but nothing east of Arbuckle. 11.30 A. M. Major Yard, Major Vandeweile and Mrs. V. and Badger with Co. B. just coming in.  The 4 cos. started from Dodge, and when two days out, all but Co. B. were ordered back.  I cant learn for what purpose but Vandeweile thinks they will come in detachments as excort to trains coming through with supplies.  Vandeweile desires to be remembered. I have not seen the rest. Camp Wichita I. T.
May 8th, 1869
Dear General,

             I am just in receipt of a large mail and among it, your two letters of Apl. 26th and one of the 28th.   You need give yourself no uneasiness about affairs here.  Everything is running smoothly and quietly.  Companies L and D are well underway with their quarters.  Company B. is well sheltered in new A tents and [strike] which they brought with them.   The sawmill is making shingles for your house.  Badger will be assigned to duty on Monday as A. A. Q. M. and A. C. S., as it is uncertain when Beck will come down.  I will give Capt. Alvrod seven days leave to date from the time he leaves

the limits of the District with permission to apply in person at Dept. Hd. Qrs. This will in no way compromise you, and will give him plenty of time to get to Dept. Hd. Qrs.   Spencer and wife are enroute to this place.  He got a leave from the War Dept. until May 10th.   There is no necessity for more troops here at present, and unless there is, Byrne's Co. had better remain at Arbuckle, at least until you come out.   I hear from Arbuckle today that they have a flying report there, (I dont know from what source), that Forts Smith, Gibson and Arbuckle are to be garrisoned by the 6th Infantry and that you are to have an independent command here, to be composed entirely of Cavalry.   I have ordered the Hd. Qrs. 6th Infantry, Munson & Carland to Ft. Gibson.

Vandenvile met Lee about half way between here and Camp Supply getting along all right, but nearly out of Beef.      I have furnished copies of the communication in regard to Supply routes to Comdg Officer's Ft. Arbuckle & Camp Wichita, with directions to forward estimates for Q. M. stores & subsistence stores, thro' these Hd. Qrs. to Dept. Hd. Qrs. in addition to those already forwarded.  We will get supplies by some hook or crook I guess in the course of events.

   Since the capture of those Chiefs in New Mexico, we hear of all their tribes coming this way to give up.
   Sunday Morning the 9th   Have just got through with Inspection and Guard mounting.  The troops here have got their extra clothing &c. up from Arbuckle are cleaned up and look first rate.     Co. B. has a pretty good mount

Much better than M Company.   They are in tolerable good fix, except for equipment.

          Kind regards to Mrs. Grierson & Mrs. Sample
                       Yours Truly
                            S. L. Woodward

Fort Arbuckle, C.N
May 4, 1870
Dear General,

At night I hopple them with horse hopples of the detachment and chain them fast.

Fort Smith Ark
May 22d, 1875
Dear General,

             I arrived here on the 12th and have been before the Court every day since.  Every prisoner we sent down who was tried before this term of the Court has been convicted.  California Joe, got $300 fine and six months in the penitentiary, Burnside, Buckskin Joe and Renshaw who stole three mules from Major Forsyth last November received the full penalty of the law $1000 fine each and twelve months imprisonment.  Wilson and

Bancroft who stole the Indian ponies were convicted on my testimony, much to my surprise and received a sentence of $500 fine each and twelve months imprisonment.  The officials here, the Marshal, Judge and District Attorney are very cleaver and kind, and seem to appreciate the efforts we are making to bring scoundrels to justice.  Marshal Britton, says it is not his instructions to his deputies to do anything as Fort Sill which does not meet your views and receive your full sanction, and when they act otherwise it is through ignorance or rascality.

       Judge Caldwell used to be Lt. Col. of the 3d. Iowa Cavalry (Noble's regiment) and knows

you.   He is a first rate Judge, and I am fully satisfied that culprits stand a slim show to escape the law when tried before him.     I enclose a letter from Capt. Churchill the Commissioner in answer to yours enclosing the complaints against Deputy Marshal Carson.

   I also enclose a copy of a letter from Durfee to his Clerk Carroll on that Spear business.  I accidentally saw this letter and took a copy of it to show you the animus of Mr. Durfee.   I am subpoaned in this case before the next term of the Court in November next.  I think the case against them is pretty strong.

The prisoners have been taken away from me on "Habeas Corpus" and are now in jail at Van Buren.  I will send in a few days a full official report with copies of the writ and the record of the Court in these cases, which makes my record clear.

         I have heard today of a man answering the description of Spraff (who escaped from me) with handcuffs on, being in the Arkansas Bottom opposite here.  I think I will send out a party tomorrow and search the country for him.   If it is him, it has been ten days since he escaped and he has not succeeded in getting his handcuffs off.  
       Write me at Paducah Ky, as I think I shall get away from here about the last of this month.
          Very Respectfully
                S. L. Woodward

                               Washington D. C.    July 3rd 1875

Dear General

              I arrived here on Friday last and find that I shall be detained until after the fourth, before I can get through with the business I am on.    I saw Taylor yesterday, he has resigned and it is accepted to take effect Jan. 1st 1871, in the meantime he does not expect to come back to Sill.   Armes is dismissed and Kennedy is promoted Captain to fill the vacancy.   I called on Gen'. Sherman yesterday, he inquired particularly after you, also McCoy.    I have not seen Gen'l. Parker, but have heard that he and the other officials here are well pleased with your administration of affairs at Ft. Sill.  I am sorry to learn that the Indians have been committing depredations about the post since I left.  I called to

see the President, but he is out of town.  The Army bill agreed upon by the Conference Committee has not yet passed the Senate and there is a belief by some that it will not pass.  I believe it is to be considered in the Senate on Tuesday the 5th.

    I hope to leave here for Philadelphia on Tuesday night.
    Gen'l. Thomas asked me about the killing of those mule thieves and if any report had been made of it.  I told him you had made a report to Dept. Hd.qrs. and I believed Major Yard had also.    He said he had not yet seen the reports.
   I have not yet leard from you since I left Ft. Sill.  Direct to me at Rancocus, [undrline] Burlington Co. [underline] New Jersey. [underline]
   Kind regards to Mrs. Grierson, I have been quite unwell for the past three days.
                           Very truly yours,
                                 S. L. Woodward

Rancocos N. J.
July 11th 1870
Dear General,

                  I arrived here on the 8th from Washington, where I spent five days.  I wrote you from there and you have doubtless received the letter before this.  I saw Gen'l. Parker just as I was leaving and had about ten minutes talk with him.  He expressed himself as well pleased with with [strike] the manner in which Indian affairs has been conducted at Fort Sill, but thought the Indians were behaving badly.   I told him what I had seen of the efforts which were being made to break up the present policy of what we had to contend against out there in order to counteract the efforts of the "old ring."

He agreed with me, but did not know that these movements were being made among the Indians themselves, as among the politicians at Washington.

    I was quite unwell while in Washington and have had two chills since my arrival here.   I am feeling quite weak today from the effects of the last one.
    I am going to Long Branch next week to try the effects of a few sea baths.
    I have only heard from Ft. Sill once since I left there and would like very much to know the news from there.
    I saw Mr. Walker from Ft. Sill in Washington, he told me about the stealing of mules by Indians at Fort Sill and that you had gone out in person after them.  Let me know the particulars, also who they killed if any body near the post.
   Let me hear from you soon.

Kind regards to Mrs. Grierson

            Very truly yours.
              S. L. Woodward
